about_me.content: I'm Taylor Kuno, a software developer who believes AI is transforming how we build software, and I want to be part of that transformation. I work on electronic medical record software for EMTs and first responders, which feels incredibly meaningful given my background in healthcare.
qa_seeds: Give me your quick bio in your own words.
What kind of software do you build and why does it matter to you?
How does your background influence your current work?

about_me.content: Software Developer at Sansio in Duluth, Minnesota

about_me.content: Using AI tools to learn faster and build better software, especially tools that help people document effectively in high-stress situations

about_me.content: Based in Duluth, Minnesota - love the North Shore and Lake Superior

about_me.content: Before tech, I spent 7+ years working directly with people in high-stress situations as a psychometrist and youth counselor in a residential mental health program. That experience taught me how crucial good documentation tools are when someone's wellbeing is on the line.

work_experience.current_job.content: I work closely with product team members who are former EMTs - they help me understand the real-world constraints and keep me from over-engineering solutions. Our QA team member started in customer support, so she knows the product inside and out and serves as my reality check for how much change users can handle.

work_experience.current_job.content: Apple Store Submission - MobileTouch UI Overhaul
qa_seeds: Name a major project you led.
What was a big UI project you worked on?
Tell me about your App Store submission work.

work_experience.current_job.content: When I joined the MobileTouch team, our CSS was scrambled and inconsistent - mixed fonts, broken icons, accessibility issues. Since Apple's HIG has strict standards, we had a lot of work to do. I researched solutions and implemented a complete styling system using the Emotion library with a StyledComponents approach.
qa_seeds: What problem did you tackle in the UI overhaul?
How did you address accessibility and consistency?
How did you meet Apple's guidelines?

work_experience.current_job.content: This was truly a team effort - my coworker Bill, a Senior Developer, built the native application from scratch while I focused on the styling system. Our QA Specialist April studied the Apple Human Interface Guidelines extensively and scoured the application for areas needing improvement. The whole team, along with others from QA and Support, were involved in finding bugs as we went along.
qa_seeds: Who contributed to the success of the overhaul?
How did you divide responsibilities on the project?
What role did QA play?

work_experience.current_job.content: Over 300 hours of work coordinating across multiple teams
qa_seeds: How big was the project?
What was the scope and effort involved?
How many teams did you coordinate with?

work_experience.current_job.content: Apple didn't reject a single aspect of our UI during submission, and when changes went live, we only had a few minor bugs to resolve
qa_seeds: What were the results of the overhaul?
How did the App Store submission go?
What quality outcomes did you achieve?

work_experience.current_job.content: How to lead a major technical change while bringing the whole team along. Getting buy-in early made all the difference, and having teammates like Bill handling the native development and April ensuring HIG compliance made the project successful.
qa_seeds: What did you learn from that project?
How did you drive change effectively?
What made the project successful?

work_experience.current_job.content: AI Tools Leadership Initiative

work_experience.current_job.content: I've been helping lead our company's adoption of AI development tools. I test everything from GitHub Copilot to Cursor to Amazon Q, then develop strategies to help our team integrate these tools effectively.

work_experience.current_job.content: We focus on building a culture of experimentation rather than instruction. I believe developers learn AI tools best when they feel empowered rather than mandated to use them.

I've specialized in frontend and UX, but I'm becoming just as effective at building APIs and data management strategies.

healthcare_background.psychometrist_role.content: Administered neuropsychological testing to patients ages 1 to adult, built rapport quickly to ensure valid test results, and provided detailed documentation for neuropsychologists
qa_seeds: What were your core responsibilities as a psychometrist?
Who did you serve and how?
What did the job entail day to day?

healthcare_background.psychometrist_role.content: Worked with children across the full spectrum of learning differences including ADHD, autism, dyslexia, and other neurological conditions - essentially any child who needed neuropsychological evaluation
qa_seeds: Which populations did you serve?
What kinds of needs did your clients have?
Who did you primarily work with?

healthcare_background.psychometrist_role.content: Primary focus was autism spectrum disorder (ASD) evaluations
qa_seeds: Did you have a clinical focus?
What were you specialized in?
What type of evaluations did you do most?

healthcare_background.psychometrist_role.content: When standard approaches weren't working, I'd adapt my methods to meet each child where they were. Once I reengaged a patient by delivering instructions in a dinosaur voice through his favorite toy that he brought along - it helped him show his actual academic skills rather than just his distress limits.
qa_seeds: How did you adapt when protocols weren't working?
Tell me about a creative way you reengaged a child.
How did you meet kids where they were?

healthcare_background.psychometrist_role.content: Always documented any departures from standardization so neuropsychologists had complete qualitative context, ensuring we captured authentic capabilities rather than just stress responses
qa_seeds: How did you handle documentation vs. standardization?
How did you record protocol deviations?
What ensured validity in your reports?

healthcare_background.psychometrist_role.content: Building trust rapidly under pressure, maintaining standardized procedures while adapting to individual needs, multi-tasking documentation while staying focused on the person in front of me
qa_seeds: What skills did you develop in that role?
How did you balance rigor with empathy?
What capabilities did the job strengthen?

healthcare_background.psychometrist_role.content: Had to maintain perfect standardization while keeping each child calm and motivated. Required keen observation skills to record test answers accurately while also writing high-quality behavioral observations.
qa_seeds: What were the hardest parts of the job?
How did you document during difficult sessions?
What made the work challenging?

healthcare_background.psychometrist_role.content: I developed shorthand methods for tracking documentation on the fly and learned to systemize my process to record things accurately while staying attentive to the patient's experience
qa_seeds: What systems did you create for documentation?
How did you stay accurate under pressure?
How did you balance note taking and patient focus?

healthcare_background.psychometrist_role.content: Spending hours scoring tests manually led me to create Excel programs to streamline the process and catch errors. This was one of my first experiences that made me curious about programming.
qa_seeds: What first drew you toward programming?
How did you start automating healthcare tasks?
What made you curious about coding?

healthcare_background.psychometrist_role.content: Helping children receive correct diagnoses meant they could access services they needed to thrive. This experience taught me how crucial accurate documentation is when someone can't advocate for themselves.
qa_seeds: Why did that work matter to you?
What impact did documentation have on outcomes?
Why is accurate documentation important?

healthcare_background.project_coordinato.content: During a lull in psychometrist responsibilities, I was asked to coordinate an Epic EMR training across all outpatient specialty care clinics in the system
qa_seeds: Can you describe the Epic training you coordinated?
What did that coordination effort involve?
How did you step into the project coordinator role?

healthcare_background.project_coordinato.content: Worked with managers and practitioners across multiple clinics to help them use Epic more efficiently for documentation
qa_seeds: What was the scope of the coordination?
Who were the stakeholders?
What were you optimizing?

healthcare_background.project_coordinato.content: I saw the full spectrum of responses to new technology - some providers were already power users, others were excited to learn, and some struggled to shift their workflows for various reasons
qa_seeds: What did you learn about tech adoption?
How did providers react to the changes?
What challenges did you see with workflow shifts?

healthcare_background.project_coordinato.content: This experience directly informs how we're approaching AI tool adoption at Sansio. The one-on-one mentoring sessions were crucial for helping skeptical or less technical users trust the process and try something new
qa_seeds: How does that experience shape your current AI rollout?
What tactics help with skeptical users?
How do you build trust during tool adoption?

healthcare_background.project_coordinato.content: Learned about the real difficulties of documentation and meeting patient needs, which motivates me to make our EMT software as user-friendly as possible

healthcare_background.youth_counselor_ex.content: Provided basic needs, maintained safety, guided youth using strength-based interventions, facilitated core skills groups, trained other staff in de-escalation techniques
qa_seeds: What were your core responsibilities?
How did you support youth and staff?
What interventions did you use?

healthcare_background.youth_counselor_ex.content: Learning to stay calm when someone else is escalating, showing comfort around people in vulnerable states to build trust and create safety
qa_seeds: How did you manage crises?
How did you build trust in escalated situations?
What did you learn about staying calm?

healthcare_background.youth_counselor_ex.content: Had to do narrative documentation, often pen-and-paper during crisis situations, then write things up on computer later. It was challenging remembering details after time had passed - would have been useful to have better in-the-moment documentation tools
qa_seeds: What was documentation like in that role?
How did you handle notes during crises?
What were the limitations of your tooling?

healthcare_background.youth_counselor_ex.content: Managing conflicting priorities of patient safety and documentation relied on established procedures and high levels of teamwork. Having well-defined processes that everyone was trained on was crucial for stepping into high-stress situations with everyone on the same page
qa_seeds: What processes supported effective teamwork?
How did you balance safety and documentation?
What made high-stress teamwork effective?

healthcare_background.youth_counselor_ex.content: These experiences help me sympathize with EMT work and give me lived understanding of how having the right documentation system can make a big difference in patient outcomes
qa_seeds: How does this experience inform your EMT software work?

personal_projects.ai_portfolio_website.content: Sometimes suggested risky options like dangerouslySetInnerHTML, made novice mistakes like missing closing div tags, occasionally broke everything when making adjustments

personal_projects.ai_portfolio_website.content: Had to reject dangerouslySetInnerHTML suggestion - always avoid outdated and risky options

personal_projects.ai_portfolio_website.content: Go slow and read the output, ask for explanations if you don't know something, request multiple options with pros and cons for infrastructure decisions, experiment with different prompts

education.chemistry.content: My chemistry background gave me strong analytical thinking skills and experience with complex systems, which directly informs my approach to software architecture and problem-solving. The research experience taught me how to methodically test hypotheses and document findings - skills I use daily in software development.
